Least Squares

Find x‚Éó\vec{x}xÔªø such that Ax‚Éó‚âàb‚ÉóA\vec{x} \approx \vec{b}Ax‚âàbÔªø by minimizing ‚à£‚à£Ax‚Éó‚àíb‚Éó‚à£‚à£2||A\vec{x}-\vec{b}||^2‚à£‚à£Ax‚àíb‚à£‚à£2Ôªø

It is relatively easy to minimize the squared norm rather than the norm because now the squared norm is differentiable and convex(any local minimum is a global minimum)

Solution:

We can either derive the solution by minimizing derivative of ‚à£‚à£Ax‚Éó‚àíb‚à£‚à£2||A\vec{x}-b||^2‚à£‚à£Ax‚àíb‚à£‚à£2Ôªø or projecting b‚Éó\vec{b}bÔªø to Col(A)Col(A)Col(A)Ôªø - column space of matrix AAAÔªø.

Intuition of method 2 (projection) ‚áí projection of b‚Éó\vec{b}bÔªø onto Col(A)Col(A)Col(A)Ôªø would form a right angle triangle and we know that perpendicular distances are the shortest.

Convex Set

Set CCCÔªø is convex if any line segment joining any two points in the set is contained in the set.

OR

Set CCCÔªø is convex if any convex combination of points inside the set is contained inside the set

Extreme Point of Polyhedron PPPÔªø:

  • We cannot find two vectors for x‚Éó\vec{x}xÔªø as a convex combination of other two points y‚Éó\vec{y}y‚ÄãÔªø and z‚Éó\vec{z}zÔªø

Fact:

  • PPPÔªø has an extreme point iff P does not contain a line

If we assume

  • PPPÔªø has an extreme point
  • Opt. solution exists and is finite

Then:

  • There exists an optimal solution that is an extreme point of PPPÔªø

Proof:

  • QQQÔªø is also a polyhedron (expressed with inequality constraints
  • Q‚äÜPQ \sube PQ‚äÜPÔªø, so QQQÔªø cannot contain a line.
    • QQQÔªø has an extreme point

If uuuÔªø is a vertex of QQQÔªø, how do we prove uuuÔªø is a vertex of PPPÔªø

then ‚àÉy,z‚ààP,y,z‚â†u\exists y, z \in P, y, z \ne u‚àÉy,z‚ààP,y,zÓÄ†=uÔªø and Œªy+(1‚àíŒª)z=u,Œª‚àà(0,1)\lambda y + (1-\lambda) z = u, \lambda \in (0,1)Œªy+(1‚àíŒª)z=u,Œª‚àà(0,1)Ôªø

We know since p‚àóp^*p‚àóÔªø is the optimal,

Cone: Set of points C‚äÜRnC \sube \mathbb{R}^nC‚äÜRnÔªø is a cone iff ‚àÄx‚Éó‚ààC,‚àÄŒ±‚â•0,Œ±x‚Éó‚ààC\forall \vec{x} \in C, \forall \alpha \ge 0, \alpha \vec{x} \in C‚àÄx‚ààC,‚àÄŒ±‚â•0,Œ±x‚ààCÔªø.

  • Convex Cone
    • A cone CCCÔªø is convex iff ‚àÄŒ∏1,Œ∏2‚â•0,Œ∏1x‚Éó1+Œ∏2x‚Éó2‚ààC\forall \theta_1, \theta_2 \ge 0, \theta_1 \vec{x}_1 + \theta_2 \vec{x}_2 \in C‚àÄŒ∏1‚Äã,Œ∏2‚Äã‚â•0,Œ∏1‚Äãx1‚Äã+Œ∏2‚Äãx2‚Äã‚ààCÔªø
  • Polyhedral Cone
    • C={(x‚Éó,t)‚à£Ax‚Éó‚â§b‚Éót,t‚ààR,t‚â•0}C = \{ (\vec{x},t) | A\vec{x} \le \vec{b}t, t \in \mathbb{R}, t \ge 0 \}C={(x,t)‚à£Ax‚â§bt,t‚ààR,t‚â•0}Ôªø
  • Ellipsoidal Cone
    • Equation for Ellipse
      • x‚ä§Px+q‚ä§x+r‚â§0,P>0x^\top P x + q^\top x + r \le 0, P > 0x‚ä§Px+q‚ä§x+r‚â§0,P>0Ôªø OR
      • ‚à£‚à£Ax+b‚à£‚à£22‚â§c2||Ax+b||_2^2 \le c^2‚à£‚à£Ax+b‚à£‚à£22‚Äã‚â§c2Ôªø, x‚ä§A‚ä§Ax+2b‚ä§Ax+b‚ä§b‚àíc2‚â§0x^\top A^\top A x + 2 b^\top A x + b^\top b -c^2 \le 0x‚ä§A‚ä§Ax+2b‚ä§Ax+b‚ä§b‚àíc2‚â§0Ôªø
    • Ellipsoidal Cone Equation
      • C={(x,t);‚à£‚à£Ax+bt‚à£‚à£2‚â§ct}C = \{ (x,t) ; ||Ax + bt||_2 \le ct \}C={(x,t);‚à£‚à£Ax+bt‚à£‚à£2‚Äã‚â§ct}Ôªø
      • (Œ±x,Œ±t)‚ààC,‚àÄŒ±‚â•0,(x,t)‚ààC(\alpha x, \alpha t) \in C, \forall \alpha \ge 0, (x,t) \in C(Œ±x,Œ±t)‚ààC,‚àÄŒ±‚â•0,(x,t)‚ààCÔªø
    • Special Case:
      • Second-Order Cone

Seperating Hyperplane

A seperating hyperplane of data is

such that

  • If w‚Éó‚ä§x‚Éói+b>0\vec{w}^\top \vec{x}_i + b > 0w‚ä§xi‚Äã+b>0Ôªø then yi=+1y_i = +1yi‚Äã=+1Ôªø
  • If w‚Éó‚ä§x‚Éói+b<0\vec{w}^\top \vec{x}_i + b < 0w‚ä§xi‚Äã+b<0Ôªø then yi=‚àí1y_i = -1yi‚Äã=‚àí1Ôªø

Define distance to hyperplane from a class to be the minimum of all distances of all points in the class to the hyperplane.

So formulation of SVM:

If (m,w‚Éó,b)(m, \vec{w}, b)(m,w,b)Ôªø is a solution, then (m,Œ±w‚Éó,Œ±b)(m, \alpha \vec{w}, \alpha b)(m,Œ±w,Œ±b)Ôªø is also a solution ‚áí there‚Äôs unlimited representation, so let‚Äôs impose norm on w‚Éó\vec{w}wÔªø!
